prompt: What is the primary purpose of implementing VLANs in a data centre?
options: To increase collision domains
To create separate broadcast domains for easier management
To eliminate the need for routing
To combine all devices into one logical network
explanation: VLANs segregate the network into smaller logical groups, creating separate broadcast domains that are easier to manage. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: How is a VLAN best defined?
options: A physical grouping of switches in a rack
A collection of network nodes logically grouped into a separate broadcast domain
A routing protocol used between switches
A security feature that replaces firewalls
explanation: A VLAN is defined as a collection of network nodes logically grouped together to form a separate broadcast domain, regardless of physical location. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: Which port mode is typically used to connect end-user devices such as laptops or servers?
options: Trunk (Tagged)
Access (Untagged)
Native
Hybrid
explanation: Access (untagged) ports typically connect to end-user devices and belong to a single VLAN. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: What configuration option allows a trunk port to carry untagged traffic?
options: family ethernet-switching
native-vlan-id
interface-range
vlan-tagging disable
explanation: The native-vlan-id configuration option allows trunk ports to send and receive untagged traffic. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: Which statements correctly describe trunk (tagged) ports? (Select all that apply.)
options: They can carry traffic for multiple VLANs
They are typically used between switches or edge routers
They tag frames with a VLAN ID
They only support a single VLAN
explanation: Trunk ports support multiple VLANs, are typically used between switches or routers, and separate traffic by tagging frames with a VLAN ID. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: Which statements are true about access (untagged) ports? (Select all that apply.)
options: They usually belong to a single VLAN
They connect to end-user devices
They send and receive untagged frames
They tag all frames by default
explanation: Access ports typically belong to one VLAN, connect to end-user devices, and handle untagged Ethernet frames. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: Which fields are part of the VLAN Tag Control Information (TCI)? (Select all that apply.)
options: PCP (Priority Code Point)
DEI (Drop Eligible Indicator)
VID (VLAN Identifier)
TTL (Time to Live)
explanation: The TCI contains PCP (3 bits), DEI (1 bit), and VID (12 bits). TTL is not part of VLAN tagging. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: True or False: By default, all EX Series switch ports are configured as access ports and assigned to the default VLAN.
explanation: True. By default, all switch ports are set to access mode and assigned to the default VLAN. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: True or False: VLAN tagging inserts 4 bytes into an Ethernet frame.
explanation: True. VLAN tagging inserts 4 bytes into the Ethernet frame, which includes the TPID and TCI fields. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview

prompt: Match the VLAN tagging field to its function.

answers: Identifies the VLAN the frame belongs to
Allows untagged traffic on a trunk port

explanation: PCP defines priority, DEI indicates drop eligibility, VID identifies the VLAN, and native-vlan-id allows untagged traffic on trunk ports. Module 5: Virtual Networks Overview
